On Juneteenth, we encourage our students and families, staff and community to learn and reflect.

From the Minnesota Department of Education: Today is Juneteenth Freedom Day in Minnesota. As we observe this day, we are both joyful for the progress we've made and somber for all that is left still to do. Juneteenth is the oldest known regular celebration commemorating the ending of slavery in the United States that is celebrated across the country. It began on June 19, 1865 when enslaved people in Texas learned of President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation. As the most remote of the Confederate states, Texas was the last state to have the proclamation announced after the end of the Civil War. It was two and a half years after the law had taken effect.

You can celebrate Juneteenth by spending some time learning more about the history and evolution of this holiday. https://nmaahc.si.edu/blog-post/historical-legacy-juneteenth

Dear Families:

In response to the events in Minneapolis and St. Paul, and concerns that elements of non-peaceful protests may occur locally, the City of Bloomington has issued a curfew from 8 p.m. tonight (Saturday, May 30) to 6 a.m. Sunday, May 31.

The intent of the curfew is to protect all of the citizens of our community during this difficult time.

We encourage our students and families to honor the curfew.

Last evening we witnessed a peaceful gathering of students and adults at the intersection of 98th Street and Lyndale Avenue in memory of George Floyd. We will continue to support our students and families who wish to gather and peacefully express their pain and protest recent events; however, tonight, please honor the curfew.

Thank you for your cooperation. Please take care of each other.

Les Fujitake
Superintendent of Schools

We are monitoring developments regarding coronavirus and COVID-19 in partnership with Bloomington Public Health and the Minnesota Department of Health.

While a new type of illness can be scary, we can protect our students, staff and the broader community by using simple everyday actions that protect people from other types of respiratory or flu-like illnesses.

- Thoroughly wash hands.
- Cover every cough or sneeze.
- Clean classroom tables/surfaces frequently.
- Keep kids at home for at least 24 hours after there is no longer a fever or signs of a fever (without the use of fever-reducing medicine).

Congratulations to a few of our staff members doing big things!

Beth Flottmeier, literary coach at Oak Grove Elementary School, is one of 40 educators from around the state to be selected to the Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in English Language Arts Revision Committee. The group will recommend changes to the current standards based on research, updated standards from other states and public input, ensuring that the standards promote culturally sustained learning and align with K-12 and early learning standards.

Rick Ballew, fifth grade instrumental music specialist, has been selected to Google's Certified Innovator program, which draws educators from over 50 countries to grow professionally, advocate for innovative technologies and drive school transformation. Ballew posed the question, "How might we make finding artistic works that represent our diverse student population easier?" in his application.

So many of our staff members go above and beyond, making Bloomington an exciting place to work and learn!
